lines: P R O C E E D I N G S
WITNESS:  Nobody is going to give you analogy A for your
particular field.  You got to find out different
elements from analogy from different fields all around
the world.  This is exactly what we did in Chevron
when I worked for them.
MR JOHN SMITH
Last but not least, we have to control our
professional insight into problems we encounter.
We're not going to get 80, 85 per cent recovery when
the reservoir is heterogeneous, when there is water
influx, whether edge water or bottom water.  It
doesn't matter.
When water hits the gas, it's not like a piston
displacement.  It's a porous medium six water meanders
through gas and traps the gas and I'm going to show it
to you, sir.  A huge amount of gas can be trapped when
the reservoir influx.
1   Q. So this is a summary of what should have happened and
what didn't happen?
A. Now, we're moving to the next slide, which is the
fundamental principles of reservoir management.
CHAIRMAN:  We'll be discussing the guiding principles in
what we're doing.
We'll be discussing what happened in terms of
reservoir management of this field.
A. And I was able to see a document that Government of
India/DGH had regarding avoiding over-production,
preventing early water breakthrough and optimising
recovery.  It is realised, but can we practice these
things?
MR SALVE:  So now you are in India.  You got to love
elephant also.  In fact, my name is named after the
elephant God, Ganesha.
So we look at how do we balance ourselves as
a reservoir management manager:
"We have a big load to carry.  Do this weekly and
you will be able to extract more gas.  We all know
investment confidence is proportional to the certainty
of the outcome."
So investment decision in D1-D3 required is
special care.  We need to be cautious and judicious.
In our forecast of OGIP recovery factor, RF, reserves,
facilities design and reservoir management.
In Hindi, or Gujarati, we have a proverb "Hindi
spoken", translated in English "a cautious person is
always happy."
Then we look at exposure to risks can be optimised
through economic honesty in estimating OGIP and
reserves.
Maybe a cautious person would never go into
hydrocarbon recovery?
A. Sir, I am cautious person and I have made a very good
living in the hydrocarbon business, for the last
55 years.
CHAIRMAN:  But you're over there in Houston.  You can't
do all of the cases that come up, including in India,
and the contractor had very good technical advisory
people.  You say they made mistakes and that's what
we've got to focus on.
But amongst the many differences, that's the
nature of professionalism?
A. Absolutely.  Just like two doctors have slightly
different opinions regarding the same patient at times
and that is okay.
Technical sincerity regarding connectivity,
deliverability, delta "P", pressure drop, excessive
production rates.  These are what to focus on in
bringing the humility.
What I have learned is that more I study, more
I feel I know less about the subject.  Because things
are complicated and we have to realise respect the
force of nature.
So now we moving to risk and uncertainties.
Definition of risk, exposure to danger, but that can
be minimised through preventive measures.
These are the GIPIP of our industry.  Definition
of uncertainty, there are multiple outcomes.  Because
there is insufficient information.
We cannot eliminate the risk, but how we manage
the risk and reduce the uncertainty is very important.
In our business, sir, there is no silver bullet, but
E&P industry continues to flourish.
Today US is producing 13.3 million barrels of oil
per day.  Production in the US is higher than ever
been before.  So this industry is flourishing.  We
just have to be careful and manage the projects
appropriately.
I always believe defence wins the championship.
CHAIRMAN:  So that's the philosophy I have always
followed.
Now look at approach, especially if we don't know
enough about our reservoir and is listed in this
particular slide in a sequential way what we could do
to make a project like this successful.
I'm not going to glance through them.  They are
described in a sequential phase.
2   Q. Kindly look at this item 3, "EWT", extended well test,
"EPT", early production test, and producing a few
wells very fast, producing a few wells early on for
a limited time and creating the data that you create
in the production phase you create that data early on.
You collect that data early on?
A. And you calibrate your reservoir model to make
a forecast.  Then this is what we followed exactly in
2004 in the Jansz and Sanholo fields in the deep water
of Gulf of Mexico.
I'm very proud to tell you, sir, that was a very
difficult formation called Wilcox formation.  The net
to gross ratio in that field is even more complicated
than D1-D3.
So I didn't know how to make a production forecast
just using simulation and material balancing equation.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  So what we had to do?
A. Is do early production test.  Because production test
is your gold standard for these kind of projects.
3   Q. Geological means and geophysical means alone.
It has to be holistic.  It has to be integrated?
A. So now we move to the guiding principles of GIPIP and
UK has done a great job in providing a good field
development planning guidelines that you see the
reference here.  Once again, EWT is extended well test
that you produce the well for an extended time period.
Early test is very similar and you produce the
well as early as possible and collecting the data.
The purpose of EWT and/or ep T is to obtain
essential field and then reservoir information and
follow a phased development approach by producing and
production, in a phased development approach is what
we need to follow.
The key fact, features of FDP also and will be an
explanation of the commitments that the licensees are
making regarding facilities, number of wells, to bring
forward a sound development.
(Short break)
CHAIRMAN:  The operator did not estimate reserves
properly.
A. There was improper characterisation of reservoir.
Reservoir simulation was not used effectively,
sensitivity analysis were not performed appropriately.
The drive mechanisms were not simulated effectively.
Any time an operator doesn't follow the process,
we get burned.  If we follow the process, still there
is no 100 per cent guarantee, but the chance of
success is very high -- very high.
4   Q. So this is coming out of directly PRMS 2007 is what
often happens, and we had in D1-D3, such as those
involving water influx we had water influx.
So we had multi-phase behaviour:
"We have a multi-layered system and then it's like
this and it means this means the reservoir is not like
a sand box."
A. The reservoir has many layers like a layered cake and
each layer has sometimes different permeabilities.  So
the gas and water phases flow at different velocities
in these layers.
5   Q. So there is no way you can stop the water.  So
overproducing a given field at a high rate in
a multi-layered reservoir, come on, it's not possible.
Also the predictive models are most reliable in
estimating recoverable reserves when there is enough
production historical data, which wasn't here present.
So can't rely on models only.  You got to be
cautious.  You got to be ready?
A. For these kind of scenarios.  If we are not careful,
we get burned.
JUSTICE KHARE:  That's exactly what happens.
A. Guiding principles for GIPIP models must match
reality.  Validate the model.  Don't just model it.
Because if the models are not validated, they are not
useful.  They're only a scientific tool.  How do we
use that scientific tool is also very important.
In IDL situation, if the reservoir was completely
homogeneous in the D1-D3 field, if all the sands
behave the same way, if they were continuous, if they
were isotropic, that means permeabilities in different
directions are the same and if there is sufficient
high quality pressure data is available, just having
the pressure data from the MDT is not that useful for
material balance methodology.
If we rely on material balance only, we're going
to get surprises.  This is what we got to focus on.
The predictive models are most reliable in estimating
recoverable quantities when there is sufficient
production history to validate the model.  If we don't
have this, we got difficulties.
Moving now onto reserves.  What we see here on
this graph on the right side is the reserves value on
the vertical axis and they are proved reserves, P1,
with more than 90 per cent confidence.  Equal to or
more than 90 per cent confidence.
Horizontal axis gives different estimates which
are available.
These are by different reports, GCA, D&M, PGS, RIL
and different sized entities have come up with
different estimates of P1 reserves.
If you look at the values until 2006, until 2007,
except for one value, where would be our P1 reserves
estimates from this data?  Can anybody guess?
My honourable counsel, can you guess the values
that we would get?
You know, anybody can guess the value is going to
be 7 or 8.  No, that's an outlier.  The value is going
to be around 3 plus/minus -- 3.5.
Well, in this field, we've produced 2.3.
6   Q. That's what you're looking for.
A. P1 reserves, especially in the US, Security and
Exchange Commission goes after you in your P1 reserves
are off.  Look at what happened to Shell in 2004.
CHAIRMAN:  I saw that mentioned in a footnote at some
stage I'd be interested to know?
A. Absolutely, sir.  Absolutely, sir.
P1 reserves, it is really like in the US, when
I worked in the reserves, evaluation -- by the way,
for Chevron I worked 15 years in the reserves
evaluation for all over the world.
CHAIRMAN:  Yes, but you're one person, a very skilled and
expert person.  There are lots of people with
expertise and they have to also be used in faraway
countries.  I mean, this is a worldwide thing.
A. Absolutely.  Thank you, sir.
So P1 reserves we have to be very accurate.
P2 frankly speaking, Security and Exchange
Commission in the US.
Does not even pay attention to.  They're not going
to check you on that.  But on P1 if you're wrong, they
are going to take care of us.  So we got to be just
right in P1.
So now let's move to project management process,
PMP, to create maximum value.
You may recall this picture comes from WRMP.  This
picture is used by Chevron, in the Gorgon field, in
the Jansz field of the gas production.
What this picture shows is that it's not possible
to find the value on the vertical axis on the
horizontal, says from phase 1 to phase 5.  Just
like this.
7   Q. What it shows is that if you define the project
properly, and if you execute the project properly, you
create tremendous value.  When we are unable to define
the project clearly, on top of that when we execute
the project also not so properly, we get a poor result
like estimate D.
A. In a case like Ormen Lange in Norway, which we have
referred in our statements before, when we see there
is that they had forecasted --
8   Q. And now we're talking about Shell and State Oil
managing that project in Norway, their forecast was
12 TCF -- very similar capital expenditures.
They have already produced 10 TCF.  That was
a wonderful performance -- wonderful performance.
Somebody that you like to give a grade of A.
9   Q. Look at the situation we face here.  Poor project
definition.
A. Poor execution.
10  Q. Our forecast of 10 TCF, 10.03, management committee
report, a consensus, then result is 2.3.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  Can I just say that -- no.  So you can
just ignore me.
WITNESS:  Please.
MR SALVE:  I was, in fact, going to point out it's almost
5 past 11.00.  We are on page 16 and he has 45 pages
yet to go on to.  How can he finish in time.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  I was going to wait until 11.15, which
is an hour.
CHAIRMAN:  This is very interesting and very useful,
Prof Thakur.
But we have to keep our eye on the clock, because
we only have three days to hear very distinguished
experts being cross-examined.  Therefore, if you could
find a way -- in consultation with Prof Kondapi -- to
squeeze it.
You've got over some very important points, but
we've got to watch the clock which I'm sure you
understand?
A. Thank you, sir.  I will try to follow.
But most important thing is that you have the
slides to read and all the things that I'm planning to
convey, they are documented in the slides.  So I'll go
a little bit faster.
So now we look at the gas reserve field
development planning.
11  Q. We are aware of these things already very well, so I'm
going to, for the time being, I'm going to skip this
slide.  I'm going to go to next slide, which is
regarding recovery factor calculation.
A. Recovery factor calculation for a gasfield or any
hydrocarbon field has to be consistent with the drive
mechanism.
If you have depletion drive:
"You are going to get high recovery.  If you got
water influx, there is no way you're going to get
85 per cent recovery -- no way.  Technically
impossible."
So what I have done here is -- and this is what
AIDP mentions when they use a value of 85 per cent.
Then they are going to look at the UK publications on
oil and gas recovery and they list the field with
depletion, dry gas reservoirs recoveries, number of
fields on the vertical axis, on the horizontal axis is
the recovery range.
So you're going to get some reservoirs with
85 per cent recovery, but you're going to get lot of
reservoirs with 35, 45, 55, 65 recoveries and they are
without water influx.
12  Q. So when you add water influx to it, these curves,
these graphs, they shift to the left.
Where do we stand in D1-D3?
A. I give you an example analogy of the Ram Powell field,
which has been utilised by the claimant also in the
Gulf of Mexico.  The field was discovered in 1985.
Please kindly refer to those papers.
13  Q. Which are being provided?
A. And they had similar issues of thin-bedded reservoirs
and they were not sure if they are going to be
contributing.  What did they do?
14  Q. They did early production testing and found gas
and oil.
A. And determined how these reservoirs are going to
contribute.
15  Q. Now, I'm going to bring an example from Angola, which
is also an oil and gas reservoir.  It has oil, it also
has gas?
A. And I would like to request you to look at bullet 2,
that using an early production system here, they were
able to test the productivity and that productivity
provided them information regarding reservoir
continuity.
16  Q. And they mention in their paper it should be noted
that these insights couldn't have been obtained by any
other method than by producing the reservoir.  That's
the point I like to mention?
A. I wish we had produced the reservoir.  I wish we had
done some.
(The hearing adjourned until 10 am on the following day)
I N D E X
